_prev_prog_3.Description: Central City Cooling has prepared a unified Risk & Process Safety Management Program. The program is in compliance with California's Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program (in California CCR Title 19, Chapter 4.5 Program Level 3 Elements). At the Federal level, (Title 40 CFR Part 68), and California OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) of Acutely Hazardous Materials standard (in California CCR Title 8, Section 5189 Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials), Federally Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119). This program been prepared to address the risks involved with the presence of anhydrous ammonia in an amount in excess of 10,000 lbs., which is contained in our refrigeration system.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Central City Cooling has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 Central City Cooling, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Central City Cooling has updated their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following process which has the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name             |  Process Chemical               | Process Quantity(lbs.)

Ammonia Refrigeration       Anhydrous Ammonia                41,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. 

Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.

1. Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

2. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM regulation to meet CalARP and RMP obligatio

ns as well

3. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices



Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Description



1.2.1 Facility Overview



Central City Cooling operates a commercial cold storage for a variety of fruits and vegetables in Santa Maria, CA. The facility has an ammonia refrigeration system that provides refrigeration capacity to the following:

(3) Cold Rooms

(1) Ice Maker

(3) MAC Coolers

(4) Pressure Coolers

(2) Truck Docks

(1) Heat Exchanger (Water Chiller)

(2) Vacuum Tube Chillers

(2) Portable Vacuum Tube Chiller (Seasonal - April through November)



1.2.2 Facility Location



Central City Cooling is located at 1701 Betteravia Rd, Santa Maria, CA 93454. The latitude and longitude of the high pressure receiver is 34.924896, -120.398101. The facility is located approximately 1 mile east of state highway 101 in a rural area surrounded primarily by agriculture land.



According to FEMA Flood Map Service, the facility is located in "an area of minimal flood hazard".



Central City Cooling is not located in an Alquist-Priolo Fault Zone as defined by the California Department of Conservation. In addition, a review of United States Geological Survey (USGS) fault maps revealed the following faults within close proximity:

Santa Maria Fault - <1.6 Million Years

Bradley Canyon Fault - <1.6 Million Years

San Luis Range Fault System - <130,000 Years

West Huasna Fault Zone - <130,000 Years

The USGS 2018 One-Year Model revealed that Central City Cooling has a 1-2% chance of experiencing "potentially minor-damage" due to ground shaking in 2018.



1.2.3 Description of Covered Process



The refrigerated areas are equipped with air-cooling evaporators, accumulators, and recirculators

as required for a combination of a flooded and pumped overfeed operation.

Most control valve groups are located on the roof and adjacent to each piece of equipment outside to provide easy access. The refrigeration machinery is contained within or directly above the machinery room. A partial list of system components includes: 



Machinery Room

(6) Screw compressors

(6) Oil separators

(1) High pressure receiver

(1) Medium suction accumulator

(1) High temperature recirculator

(2) Oil pots



Condenser Area

(3) Evaporative condensers

(1) Auto-purger

(1) Diffusion tank



Low Temperature Recirculator Area

(1) Low temperature recirculator

(1) Oil pot

(1) Ice maker (six (6) modules, plate fin)

(1) Plate and frame heat exchanger



Berry Room

(8) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)



Dry Room

(8) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)



Wet Room

(8) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)



Berry Dock

(4) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)



Dock

(8) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)



Pressure Cooler 1 and 2 (single evaporator cools two (2) separate pressure coolers)

(1) Air-cooling evaporators (base-mounted, plate fin)



Pressure Cooler 3 and 4 (single evaporator cools two (2) separate pressure coolers)

(1) Air-cooling evaporators (base-mounted, plate fin)



MAC Cooler 1

(4) Air-cooling evaporators (base-mounted, plate fin)



MAC Cooler 2

(4) Air-cooling evaporators (base-mounted, plate fin)



MAC Cooler 3

(4) Air-cooling evaporators (base-mounted, plate fin)



Vacuum Tube Chiller 1

(2) Surge drums

(2) Air-cooling evaporators (base-mounted, plate fin)



Vacuum Tube Chiller 2

(2) Surge drums

(2) Air-cooling evaporators (base-mounted, plate fin)



Portable Vacuum Tube Chillers (Seasonal - April through November)

(1) Surge drum each

(1) Air-cooling evaporators (base-mounted, plate fin) each



1.2.4 Process Chemistry



High Pressure Receiver

The purpose of the high pressure receiver is to prov

ide a safe location to add and store high pressure liquid ammonia in the refrigeration system. The high pressure receiver receives high pressure liquid from the condenser and pipes high pressure liquid through the medium suction accumulator to supply each zone of refrigeration and liquid recirculator. The high pressure receiver is also used to provide storage for ammonia not being used in the process at any given moment. The high pressure receiver is equipped with a main liquid feed shut-off valve (king valve) that is clearly labeled and can be used to stop the flow of ammonia throughout the system. Under normal conditions, the high pressure receiver contains high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Surge Drum

The purpose of each surge drum is to provide a supply of low pressure liquid ammonia to the vacuum tube coils. Each surge drum is equipped with an expansion valve which expands the high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure liquid as it enters the vessel. The surge drums supply, by gravity, low pressure liquid to the associated vacuum tube coils. Liquid and vapor returned from the coils is separated inside the surge drums to allow only the vapor to be returned to the medium suction accumulator. Under normal conditions, the surge drums contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



High Temperature Recirculator

The purpose of the high temperature recirculator is to provide a supply of low pressure liquid that can be used in high temperature evaporators throughout the facility. The high temperature recirculator receives subcooled liquid from the high pressure receiver and supplies, by gravity, low pressure liquid to the ammonia pumps mounted underneath the vessel. Liquid and vapor returned from the evaporators is separated inside the recirculator to allow only the vapor to be piped to the suction of each high stage compressor. The high temperature recirculator is equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compress

ors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors. Under normal conditions, the high temperature recirculator contains low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Low Temperature Recirculator

The purpose of the low temperature recirculator is to provide a supply of low pressure liquid that can be used in low temperature Ice Makers. The low temperature recirculator receives liquid from the high temperature recirculator and supplies, by gravity, low pressure liquid to the ammonia pumps mounted underneath the vessel. Liquid and vapor returned from the Ice Makers is separated inside the recirculator to allow only the vapor to be piped to the suction of the low stage compressor. The low temperature recirculator is equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressor in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressor. Under normal conditions, the low temperature recirculator contains low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Oil Pots

The purpose of the oil pots is to provide a safe location to drain oil from the refrigeration system. The oil pots receive liquid ammonia and oil from the medium suction accumulator and recirculators and vent ammonia vapor back to the associated vessel. The oil pots are equipped with spring-return oil drain valves which are used to drain oil from the system as needed. Under normal conditions, the oil pots contain low pressure liquid ammonia, low pressure vapor ammonia, and refrigerant oil.



Air-Cooling Evaporators (Pumped Overfeed)

The purpose of the air-cooling evaporators is to remove heat from the air in order to maintain a predetermined space temperature. The air-cooling evaporators receive liquid from the high temperature recirculator. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liqu

id refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporators use an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it returns to the supplying vessel. Under normal conditions, the air-cooling evaporators contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Plate and Frame Heat Exchanger

The purpose of the plate and frame heat exchanger is to remove heat from the water being pumped through it. The plate and frame heat exchanger receives liquid from the high temperature recirculator where it flows through the channels in the plates and absorbs the heat from the water on the opposite side of each plate. Low pressure liquid and vapor exits the plate and frame heat exchanger and is returned to the recirculator. Under normal conditions, the plate and frame heat exchanger contains low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.  



Ice Makers

The purpose of the ice makers is to produce ice that can be used for packaging finished products. The ice maker receives liquid from the low temperature recirculator. Low pressure liquid and vapor exits the ice maker and is returned to the supplying vessel. Under normal conditions, the ice maker contains low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Modular Automated Cooling System (MACs) Coolers

The purpose of the MAC cooler is to remove heat from the fresh fruit that is placed within the MAC cooler chamber. The MAC cooler receives liquid from the high temperature liquid recirculator. Low pressure liquid and vapor exits the MAC cooler and is returned to the supplying vessel. Under normal conditions, the MAC cooler contains low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Vacuum Tube Chillers

The purpose of the vacuum tube chiller is to remove heat from the leafy green vegetables that are placed within the vacuum tube chamber. The vacuum tube chiller receives liquid from a floode

d accumulator. Low pressure liquid and vapor exits the vacuum tube chiller and is returned to the flooded accumulator. Under normal conditions, the vacuum tube chiller contains low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Medium Suction Accumulator

The purpose of the medium suction accumulator is to subcool the high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver. This subcooled liquid is sent to the high temperature recirculator and vacuum tube chillers. In addition, it prevents liquid from entering the compressors. The medium suction accumulator receives vapor from the surge drums and separates any residual liquid from the vapor to allow only the vapor to be piped to the suction of each compressor. The medium suction accumulator is equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors. Under normal conditions, the main suction accumulator contains low pressure vapor ammonia.



Compressors

The purpose of the compressors is to raise the temperature and pressure of the low pressure gas in order to reject the heat absorbed in the evaporator to the atmosphere. The compressors receive low pressure vapor from the medium suction accumulator or recirculator and discharge high pressure vapor to the evaporative condensers. The compressors are equipped with high discharge pressure cutouts to shut the equipment off if the pressure exceeds the setpoint. Under normal conditions, the compressors contain both high and low pressure vapor ammonia.



Evaporative Condensers

The purpose of the evaporative condensers is to reject the heat absorbed in the evaporators to the atmosphere. The evaporative condensers receive high pressure, superheated vapor from the compressors and supply high pressure liquid to the high pressure receiver. The condensers use air and water to cool the warm ammonia as it passes through a series of tubes within the condenser. As the c

curity alarm monitoring company which in turn will call facility personnel in the event of an alarm.



Emergency Pressure Control System

The emergency pressure control system (EPCS) was installed in accordance with the 2007 California Fire Code. The EPCS consists of a crossover solenoid valve which connects the high stage discharge (HSD) pipe to the high temperature suction (HTS) pipe. The EPCS operates as follows: 

EPCS is activated at not greater than 90% pressure relief valve setting (e.g. 270 psig or less) [ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Appendix I.4.5.3] 

Upon activation, all compressors are stopped by a means that is independent of all other safety controls [ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Appendix I.4.5.6] 

Upon activation, crossover solenoid valve is opened [ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Appendix I.4.5.6] 

Upon activation, a signal is provided to personnel responsible for refrigeration system maintenance [ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Appendix I.4.5.7] 

EPCS remains active until manually reset [ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Appendix I.4.5.8]

EPCS crossover isolation valves are locked open [ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Appendix I.4.4.2] 



Relief Valves

All ASME pressure vessels and positive displacement compressors are equipped with relief valves designed to relieve pressure and protect the equipment from rupturing. Details regarding the relief valves are summarized below:

Each relief valve has a set pressure equal to or less than the MAWP of the equipment that the relief valve protects;

Each relief valve has a capacity which meets or exceeds the requirement of ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Addendum A ?15.3.8;

All relief valves are connected to a common manifold which terminates into the ammonia diffusion tank;



Diffusion Tank

The refrigeration system is equipped with an ammonia diffusion tank which mitigates most of the hazards associated with a relief valve lifting. The relief valve discharge piping is terminated at the bottom of the ammonia diffusion tank. The ammonia diffusion tank is 8' dia. x 16' high (6,000 gallon capacity). A

t a water level of 14'-0", the tank contains 5,263 gallons of water which exceeds the quantity recommended by ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Addendum A ?15.5.3 which is based on 1 gallon of water per pound of ammonia released through the largest relief valve in the system in 60 minutes. Under normal conditions, the ammonia diffusion tank contains water.



Screw Compressor Safety Devices

Each screw compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment. The following list summarizes the safety devices built into each screw compressor package:

High Discharge Pressure Cutout - The high discharge pressure cutout, will shut down the compressor if the discharge pressure equals or exceeds the setpoint.

Low Suction Pressure Cutout - The low suction pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the suction pressure is equal to or less than the setpoint.

Oil Pressure Cutout - The oil pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil pressure equals or deviates below the setpoint.

High Oil Temperature Cutout - The high oil temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil temperature equals or exceeds the setpoint.

Low Oil Temperature Cutout - The low oil temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil temperature equals or falls below the setpoint.

Discharge Temperature Cutout - The high discharge temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the discharge temperature equals or exceeds the setpoint.



High Level Float Switch

The high temperature recirculator, low temperature recirculator, and medium suction accumulator are equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high liquid level in the vessel. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors.



Main Liquid Feed Shut-Off Valve (King Valve)

The high pressure receiver is equipped with a main liquid feed shut-off valve (king valve) and a main liquid solenoid shut-off valve (king soleno

id) that is clearly labeled and can be used to stop the flow of ammonia throughout the system.



Emergency Refrigeration Switch (E-Stop)

The principal entrance to the machinery room is equipped with an emergency refrigeration switch (e-stop) that controls power to the refrigeration machinery inside the machinery room. The switch can be activated in an emergency by opening the box and pressing the red button.



1.2.6 Process Classification



The ammonia refrigeration system at Central City Cooling consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. As such, the refrigeration system at Central City Cooling is treated as a single process.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meetings we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Central City Cooling has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration process at the Central City Cooling facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. The ammonia process contains a total charge of approximately 41,000 lbs. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep active records of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the pro

cess is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 



1.4 Five Year Accident History



Central City Cooling has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Central City Cooling's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

Cal/OSHA's Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR ?3220

U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38

Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR ?5189(n)

U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements] - Title 29 CFR ?1910.119(n)

California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 ?2765.1-2765.2

USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR ?68.95

California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 ?2731

California "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 8 CCR Title 8 ?5192(q)

Federal "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 29 CFR ?1910.120(q)



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Central City Cooling has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Central City Cooling continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of t

he RMP-PSM program. This has improved Central City Cooling's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Central City Cooling's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.

Central City Cooling has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Central City Cooling has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.



For the future, Central City Cooling now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Central City Cooling employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Central City Cooling will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
